newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Yeltsin firmly backs Russia-Belarus union - Kremlin.
newsitem.headline: Yeltsin firmly backs Russia-Belarus union - Kremlin.

text.p: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is a "firm and consistent" supporter of a union between Russian and Belarus, the Kremlin said on Tuesday.

Interfax news agency quoted Yeltsin's press secretary, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, as saying the Kremlin leader thought it necessary to sign a treaty on a union with Belarus on Wednesday and then allow one month for public discussion of its status.

"President Yeltsin states clearly and unequivocally that he is an initiator of the unification of the two fraternal states and their peoples, a consistent and firm supporter of it," a Kremlin spokesman quoted Yastrzhembsky as telling reporters.
He said discussion of a charter on Russian-Belarussian union should not be in the form of a referendum.

Yeltsin and Belarussian President Alexander Lukashenko are expected to sign a Union Treaty on Wednesday. The document provides for close coordination of foreign, military and economic policies but the two Slav states will remain independent.
The draft document has provoked arguments among the Russian political elite and is firmly opposed by the nationalist opposition in Minsk.
